results.title: The Mahabharata; Episode 3: The War.
results.creator_credit: Peter Brook, Michael Propper and RM Associates
results.brief_description: The War: third part of the Sanskrit epic that is the origin of a thousand beliefs, legends, reflections and characters, still present and recognisable in contemporary culture. This is the final battle where in effect, the Pandavas and the Kauravas exterminate each other, and most of humanity while they’re about it. Yudhisthira arrives at the gate of Paradise, but they won’t let his dog in, given which he won’t enter either - all the more so on realising that, inexplicably, all the Kauravas are in Paradise and all the Pandavas in hell. We thus end on a note of absolute inexplicability of the divine powers - what was the cosmic war for? Adapted from the play by Jean-Claude Carriere. Adapted from the play by Jean-Claude Carriere.

results.title: A Caribbean mystery
results.creator_credit: Christopher Petit, George Gallaccio and BBC Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.
Miss Marple, (Joan Hickson) is far away from her home in quiet St. Mary Mead. However, even in the tropical paradise of the Caribbean, her powers of observation and keen understanding of human nature is required to solve the murder of Major Pulgrave at the Golden Palm Hotel. When others become victims to the unknown murderer she knows it’s vital for her to crack the case. Also stars Donald Pleasence.

results.title: Queen Elizabeth 2 sails around New Zealand and Australia
results.brief_description: Doug Jones sets sail with the QE2 for a voyage ‘down under’ to New Zealand and Australia. He explores Rotorua and its geothermal world of mudpots, geysers and steaming lakes and cliffs, the Tasman Galcier in a ski plane , as well as visiting Auckland, Wellington, Christchurch and Queenstown. In Australia the Sydney Opera House is visited, as is a sheep station while shearing is underway. A behind the scenes look is taken at life aboard the ship from the bridge and the engine control centre to the largest floating kitchens in the world.

results.title: The Last detail
results.creator_credit: Hal Ashby, Gerald Ayres and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Jack Nicholson stars in another outstanding performance as a hard-bitten professional Navy-man given the loathsome job of escortinga very young sailor to a military prison for a minor crime. Randy Quaid, as the young man, hasn’t begun to live yet, so Nicholson decides to give him a lifetime of experiences in three days!. This results in a drinking, fighting, womanising binge, unparalleled in movie history.

results.title: Red river
results.brief_description: Director Howard Hawks’ classic western stars the legendary John Wayne at the peak of his career and Montgomery Clift in his screen debut. Walter Brennan heads the outstanding supporting cast. The film is an account of the first cattle drive over the Chisholm Trail, from deep Texas to Abilene, Kansas. Authentic detail and stunning cinematography bring to life the trials and tribulations of this extraordinary challenge for the men who battled the dust, rain, heat and frustration of the long, hard drive. The demands of this rigorous journey further strain the edgy relationship between the film’s key characters. Tom Dunson (Wayne) is a self-made cattle king whose single-mindedness has turned him into a cold-blooded executioner, ruthlessly determined to take the cattle to Abilene his way. Arguably the best western ever made, “Red River” captures both the grandeur of the early West and the sheer determination of its people.

results.title: The Naked civil servant
results.creator_credit: Jack Gold, Barry Hanson and Thames Television
results.brief_description: This biographical film, based on the real life of Quentin Crisp, is briefly introduced by Crisp himself. Crisp is an effeminate homosexual, a flamboyant and witty exhibitionist whose conversation is as glittering as the lipstick and mascara he used to effect. The film, drawn from his own book, tells the story of his life: his youth in the 1930’s, his volatile relationship with his father, his ill-fated friendships, his encounters with authority in an extremely homophobic and intolerant society, and his rare moments of true happiness. Above all it tells the story of a good and honest man, determined to confront the world with the truth about himself, in order that they can learn to accept that he too is a human being with dreams and feelings just like everybody else. This is a witty and inspiring story of inner strength and fortitude, John Hurt was named Best Actor of 1975 at the British Academy Awards for his performance, and Jack Gold won the Academy’s Desmond Davis Award for his creative contribution to television.

results.title: Dating
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
Examines dating and focuses on the “first date” for teenagers. Looks at dating from the point of view of girls and boys, and first date etiquette. Also examines how other cultures see their children in relation to dating.

results.title: The Last picture show
results.creator_credit: Peter Bogdanovich, Stephen J. Friedman, BBS Productions and Columbia
results.brief_description: Released in 1971 to critical acclaim and public controversy, this modern day classic directed by Peter Bogdanovich garnered eight Academy Award nominations (including Best Picture). It was hailed as “the most important work by a young director since Citizen Kane”. A frank, bittersweet drama of social and sexual mores in small-town Texas featuring a cast led by Timothy Bottoms, Jeff Bridges and Cybill Shepherd in her debut role. Cloris Leachman and Ben Johnson each won Oscars for their work in supporting roles. The characters created by Larry McMurty in his compelling novel are vividly brought to life in one of the most engaging coming-of-age stories ever filmed.

results.title: Conflict of interest (D)
results.creator_credit: Tony Wellington, Ian MacArthur and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The basis of this film is the National Park and Wildlife Services kangaroo control and management program. The kangaroo is shown, historically, as a source of food for First Nations peoples, as game and a source of income for the first Europeans and today as a symbol of Australia. The Kangaroo Management Program is discussed at length. It aims to ensure the conservation of all species of macropods, the investigation of agricultural damage and the best use of product derived from culling kangaroos. Statistical information on kangaroo culling is presented diagramatically.

results.title: Without you I'm nothing
results.creator_credit: John Boskovich, Jonathan Krane and M.C.E.G.
results.brief_description: Based on Sandra Bernhard’s one-woman live show, “Without You I’m Nothing” is an ecstatic celebration of deviancy and sexual difference. Bernhard is a sardonic and biting comedian who in a series of inspired personas exposes the hypocrisy and shallowness that dominate contemporary American culture. Whether sending up her suburban Jewish upbringing or the excesses of Hollywood stardom, Bernhard’s stand-up routines reclaim the transgressive bitchiness of camp. “Without You I’m Nothing” achieves much of its power from the sheer force of Bernhard’s personality. Whether performing a lesbian-tinted “Me and Mrs Jones” or stripping to “Do You Want To Funk?”, her energy is explosive and exhilarating to watch. For lesbian and gay viewers, there is also the elation of watching a performer unapologetically celebrate the unique mixture of the kitsch, the erotic and the subversive which is central to queer notions of community and identity. The film also celebrates the pivotal contribution of African-Americans to popular music, and acknowledges how this contribution has been largely stripped of its innovation and urgency when exploited by white performers. Wicked, intelligent, sophisticated and fun, “Without You I’m Nothing” is a key work of the new Queer Cinema.
